item.title: Henri Bergius
item.description:
Henri Bergius

Hacker and an occasional adventurer. Author of Create.js and NoFlo. Decoupling software, one piece at a time.

item.title: Basic Income
item.description:
Basic Income

We're going to try something new-our first Request For Research. We'd like to fund a study on basic income-i.e., giving people enough money to live on with no strings attached. I've been intrigued by the idea for a while, and although there's been a lot of discussion, there's fairly little data about how it would work.

item.title: Three Years of Ingress and the Road for Niantic
item.description:
Three Years of Ingress and the Road for Niantic

VR vs. AR and what it means for games like Pokémon GO Wow. 2015 was a busy year for Niantic and one filled with some memorable challenges and triumphs for the team.

item.title: The Problem With Putting All the World's Code in GitHub
item.description:
The Problem With Putting All the World's Code in GitHub

The ancient Library of Alexandria may have been the largest collection of human knowledge in its time, and scholars still mourn its destruction. The risk of so devastating a loss diminished somewhat with the advent of the printing press and further still with the rise of the Internet.

item.title: Google DeepMind: Ground-breaking AlphaGo masters the game of Go
item.description:
Google DeepMind: Ground-breaking AlphaGo masters the game of Go

In a paper published in Nature on 28th January 2016, we describe a new approach to computer Go. This is the first time ever that a computer program "AlphaGo" has defeated a human professional player. The game of Go is widely viewed as an unsolved "grand challenge" for artificial intelligence.

item.title: Gridlab
item.description:
Gridlab

find inspirations and a showcase of beta sites from The Founding Members of The Grid.

item.title: The 2015 Panic Report
item.description:
The 2015 Panic Report

The complete Panic Family, circa 2015. Welcome to the 19th year of Panic. That's one heaping teaspoon of life-time, but you know what? It doesn't feel like it. I think it's because things at Panic are always evolving - gradually evolving, but evolving still, like any good business.

item.title: Dream Chaser DNA: A story of spaceplane evolution
item.description:
Dream Chaser DNA: A story of spaceplane evolution

Since the earliest days of the space age there has been something inherently attractive in the idea of a spacecraft that could glide back after its mission and land like an aeroplane. From Sanger's Silbervogel onwards, a succession of spaceplanes sporting various shapes and configurations have flowed from the minds of aerospace designers.

item.title: Why Developers Should Take Linked Data Seriously
item.description:
Why Developers Should Take Linked Data Seriously

If you aren't familiar with linked data or the Semantic Web, it's probably a good time to get better acquainted with the concepts, as it seems to be a popular theme that is rippling through the Web development world, with promises of exciting possibilities.

item.title: Web Push Arrives in Firefox 44
item.description:
Web Push Arrives in Firefox 44

Have you ever wished that a website could notify you when something important happened, even if you didn't have the site open? Maybe you've got an incoming WebRTC call, an instant message, or a financial update. Perhaps your city just declared an emergency snow plowing schedule.
